text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
During this revision, minor changes have been made and various subsections renumbered. Signiﬁcant changes to this IRM are listed in the table below:

Reference Change Details IRM 20.3.1.1.1 Changed calendar year to ﬁscal year. IRM 20.3.1.3 Updated to include accrued and/or assessed interest above $0 in the sample. IRM 20.3.1.5 Changed calendar year to ﬁscal year. Throughout Editorial changes were made throughout IRM 20.3.1.
Office of Servicewide Penalties
Table of Contents
Accuracy Review Process
) Purpose: This chapter provides background information, procedures and guidelines for the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process conducted by the Office of Servicewide Penalties (OSP). (
) Audience: This chapter contains policies and procedures for analysts in OSP to conduct the reviews independent of the civil penalty assessment and abatement functions within IRS. (
) Policy Owner: The Business Support Office (BSO) is under Operations Support (OS). SB/SE is responsible for overseeing civil penalties. (
) Program Owner: The Office of Servicewide Penalties (OSP) is responsible civil penalty policy including IRM
, Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process. OSP’s role is to ensure fairness and consistency in penalty and has overall responsibility for coordinating and approving any update to IRM
) Primary Stakeholders: Office of Servicewide Penalties (

) The Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process was developed by OSP, with sistance from the Office of the Chief Financial Officer (CFO), Internal (IC). This review process measures the accuracy of assessed and accrued penalties. Reviews are completed semi-annually (i.e. twice a ﬁscal year). Analysts located in OSP conduct the reviews independent of the civil assessment and abatement functions within IRS. (
) This process is required to be used by the Office of Servicewide Penalties (OSP) when conducting semi-annual (i.e. twice a ﬁscal year) civil penalty accuracy reviews. (
) The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) and Treasury Regulations are the primary sources of authority for the administration of penalties. Policy Statement (IRM
) mandates that the Service will design, administer, and evaluate penalty programs. This chapter was created to follow the guidance given in Policy Statement
) The Director, Business Support, is the director responsible for the civil penalty program, including the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process. (

) Overall responsibility of the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process is to OSP. OSP resides in the Business Support (Small Business/Self Function. OSP coordinates policies and procedures concerning the tion of civil penalty programs, including the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process, ensuring consistency with the penalty policy statement, reviewing analyzing penalty information, researching penalty effectiveness and ing appropriate action needed to promote voluntary compliance while protecting taxpayers’ rights. (

) Every function in the IRS has a role in proper penalty administration. It is essential that each function conduct its operations with an emphasis on promoting voluntary compliance. Appropriate reviews should be conducted ensure consistency with the penalty policy statement (Policy Statement and philosophy. Internal Revenue Manual a # Only
Owner: The Business Support Office (BSO) is under Operations (OS). SB/SE is responsible for overseeing civil penalties.
The Director, Business Support, is the director responsible for the Servicewide civil penalty program, including the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process.

Overall responsibility of the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process is assigned to OSP. OSP resides in the Business Support (Small Business/Self Employed) Function. OSP coordinates policies and procedures concerning the administra

tion of civil penalty programs, including the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review Process, ensuring consistency with the penalty policy statement, reviewing and analyzing penalty information, researching penalty effectiveness and determin
ing appropriate action needed to promote voluntary compliance while protecting taxpayers’ rights.
20.3 Penalty Program Internal Processes

(1) The terms below are deﬁned for use with this IRM. Term Deﬁnition Business Master File (BMF) Tax returns and forms found on the Business Master File that reﬂect at least one civil penalty assessment and/or abatement. Business returns and forms include, but are not limited to: a. Form 1065, U.S. Return of Partnership Income, b. Form 1120, U.S. Corporation Income Tax Return, c. Form 1120-S, U.S. Small Business Corporation Income Tax Return, d. Form 940, Employer’s Annual Federal Unemploy- ment Tax Return, and e. Form 941, Employer’s Quarterly Federal Tax Return. Civil Penalty Civil Penalties administered by IRS are detailed in IRM 20.1, Penalty Handbook. Computation sheet Worksheets developed by OSP to compute speciﬁc penalties, such as failure to ﬁle and failure to pay. Instructions for using the compu- tations sheets are detailed in the Civil Penalty Review Job Aid. Integrated Data Retrieval System Reviewers are required to use (IDRS) IDRS to conduct civil penalty review as detailed in this IRM. IDRS is a key component of the review process. Reviewers recompute all civil penalties appli- cable to a speciﬁc tax module and compare the result to the civil penalty assessments and/or abatements reﬂected on the tax module.
Worksheets developed by OSP to compute speciﬁc penalties, such as failure to ﬁle and failure to pay. Instructions for using the compu

tations sheets are detailed in the Civil Penalty Review Job Aid. Reviewers are required to use IDRS to conduct civil penalty review as detailed in this IRM. IDRS is a key component of the review process. Reviewers recompute all civil penalties appli
cable to a speciﬁc tax module and compare the result to the civil penalty assessments and/or abatements reﬂected on the tax module.

Individual Master File (IMF) Tax returns and forms found on the Individual Master File that reﬂect at least one civil penalty assessment and/or abatement (e.g. Form 1040, U.S. Individual Income Tax Return). Lead Sheet Documents developed by OSP that detail the steps to compute speciﬁc penalties, such as failure to deposit. Instructions for using the lead sheets are detailed in the Civil Penalty Review Job Aid. Penalty abatement Reversal of a civil penalty as- sessment due to reasonable cause, administrative waiver (including ﬁrst time abatement), correction of IRS error, or statutory exception (see IRM 20.1.1.3). Reviewers are required to review all civil penalty abate- ments reﬂected on a speciﬁc tax module. Penalty assessment The assessment of a civil penalty on a speciﬁc tax module when taxpayer behavior fails to meet prescribed tax obligations (see IRM 20.1.1.2). Reviewers are required to review all civil penalty assessments reﬂected on a speciﬁc tax module. Penalty as- sessment information is detailed in IRM 20.1, Penalty Handbook.
Reversal of a civil penalty as- sessment due to reasonable cause, administrative waiver (including ﬁrst time abatement), correction of IRS error, or statutory exception (see IRM
). Reviewers are to review all civil penalty abate- ments reﬂected on a speciﬁc tax module.
The assessment of a civil penalty on a speciﬁc tax module when taxpayer behavior fails to meet prescribed tax obligations (see IRM
). Reviewers are required to review all civil penalty assessments reﬂected on a speciﬁc tax module. Penalty as- sessment information is detailed in IRM
, Penalty Handbook.

Review cycle The review cycle includes the following steps: a. Planning of the review, including the securing of the sample from SB/SE Research, b. Conducting training for the review team, c. Assigning the tax modules to the reviewers, d. Conducting the reviews, e. Determining results, f. Documenting the audit trail and results, g. Identifying potential inconsis- tencies and errors, h. Referring potential inconsis- tencies and errors to subject matter experts (SMEs) for review and evaluation, i. Determining corrective actions and monitoring for completion, j. Finalizing and distributing the report of ﬁndings, and k. Continue monitoring to ensure corrective actions are imple- mented and functioning properly.

To begin each review cycle, the program manager or project lead makes a written request to SB/SE Research to identify the sample of tax modules to be reviewed. SB/SE Research provides the sample to the program manager or project lead directly. The project lead and speciﬁc penalty SMEs (see IRM
) prepare the sample for review. The program manager sets a completion date for the speciﬁc review cycle. The program manager ensures the review team is provided with adequate
The program manager ensures the review team is provided with adequate training and tools to conduct the review, including a copy of the Civil Penalty
Review Process
page Review Job Aid and all lead and computation sheets. The program manager ensures that the project lead organizes and schedules training for the reviewers (see IRM

) The program manager ﬁnalizes the report of ﬁndings. The program manager reviews and assesses the documented review process, results and actions to ensure the report of ﬁndings is accurate and complete. The report ﬁndings is considered ﬁnal when signed by the program manager. (

) The program manager shares the report with Director, Business Support and other leadership, as needed. In addition, the report of ﬁndings will be shared with the CFO, speciﬁcally Financial Management Revenue Oversight and Support (ROS) and IC. (
) The program manager ensures corrective actions are properly implemented, tested and documented as an addendum to the ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings IRM

) The program manager designates a project lead for oversight of the Civil Penalty Accuracy Review process. The project lead is an OSP analyst as an intermediary between the program manager, reviewers, SMEs, the and other internal stakeholders with an interest in the review process. (

) The project lead monitors the progress of each review cycle from of the sample through completion of the report of ﬁndings. The project lead develops the civil penalty master listing for monitoring purposes (see IRM

). The project lead should be aware of the status of the tax modules being reviewed at all times. The project lead assigns the tax modules to the reviewers and ensures all case reviews are properly tracked and The project lead maintains a listing of tax modules included in the sample. listing is referred to as the civil penalty review master listing. (

) The project lead provides instructions for completing the reviews and nicates expectations for use of the Civil Penalty Review Job Aid in the process. The project lead communicates the due date for completion of the reviews to the review team. The project lead organizes and schedules for the reviewers. The project lead coordinates with the SMEs to ensure the reviewers understand how to compute speciﬁc penalties and how to use the lead and computation sheets (see IRM

) On completion of the reviews by the reviewers, the project lead collects and compiles the results. The project lead conducts a review of the and results to ensure the documentation is complete and the ﬁndings are accurate. (

) The project lead ensures all documents related to the review process, including a copy of the ﬁnal report of ﬁndings, are uploaded to an enterprise shared folder and retained for ﬁve years from the date of issuance of the report of ﬁndings, based on IRM
) and IRM
, Records and Information Management - Types of Records and Their Life Cycles. (
) The project lead addresses questions and issues as they arise by interacting with all related parties, including Director, Business Support Office and other leadership.
The project lead addresses questions and issues as they arise by interacting with all related parties, including Director, Business Support Office and other
Penalty Program Internal (

) The project lead coordinates with the SMEs to monitor the implementation corrective actions and to ensure corrective actions are functioning properly through testing. The project lead incorporates testing results as an to the ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings (see IRM

) The penalty review team performs the reviews under the direction of the program manager, while also working in conjunction with the project lead. Generally, the team will consist of four OSP analysts, who serve as (

) Prior to conducting the reviews, the reviewers receive training and guidance ensure understanding of each speciﬁc penalty computation. Training review of the Civil Penalty Review Job Aid and direction from the SMEs on how to compute speciﬁc penalties and how to use the lead and computation sheets (see IRM
). The reviewers ensure they understand the process, including the documentation of the audit trail and conclusions and the computation of the various civil penalties identiﬁed on the tax (

) Reviewers must have access to IDRS, to conduct the reviews. Reviewers IDRS research, along with lead and computation sheets (see IRM and manual computations to review and recompute all civil penalties on the tax modules assigned. (
) Reviewers document each review, including the steps taken to recompute penalty. Reviewers maintain supporting documentation for each review on IRM
) and IRM
, Records and Information Types of Records and Their Life Cycles. (
) The reviewers communicate the results of each review to the project lead. (
) During the course of each review cycle, the review team meets periodically assess the process and address issues. (

) As part of the review team, analysts located in OSP will serve as SMEs for speciﬁc penalties. To allow for segregation of duties, reviewers should not serve as SMEs during the same review cycle. The SMEs: a. prepare the sample for assignment, b. develop lead and computation sheets to be used to review speciﬁc penalties, c. provide training to the reviewers on how to compute speciﬁc penalties, d. provide training to the reviewers on how to use the lead and sheets during the review, e. answer penalty-speciﬁc questions as the reviews are completed, f. review penalty computations to conﬁrm errors identiﬁed by the g. determine and implement corrective actions when errors are identiﬁed, h. monitor to ensure corrective actions are implemented and functioning properly, i. conduct testing to ensure corrective actions are functioning properly document results of testing, and j. provide results of testing to project lead. 20.3 Penalty Program Internal
(04-11-2018) Subject Matter Expert Responsibilities

a. prepare the sample for assignment, b. develop lead and computation sheets to be used to review speciﬁc penalties, c. provide training to the reviewers on how to compute speciﬁc penalties, d. provide training to the reviewers on how to use the lead and computation sheets during the review, e. answer penalty

speciﬁc questions as the reviews are completed, f. review penalty computations to conﬁrm errors identiﬁed by the reviewers, g. determine and implement corrective actions when errors are identiﬁed, h. monitor to ensure corrective actions are implemented and functioning properly, i. conduct testing to ensure corrective actions are functioning properly and document results of testing, and j. provide results of testing to project lead.
Penalty Accuracy Review Process 20.3.1
) On a semi-annual basis, as requested by the program manager or project lead, SB/SE Research identiﬁes the sample of tax modules to be included in each review cycle. (

) The tax modules must include at least one penalty assessment. In some cases, one tax module may include multiple penalty assessments for a of penalties. The sample is delivered directly to the program manager or project lead by SB/SE Research. (

) The sample should include tax modules that proportionately reﬂect the total population in the Unpaid Assessments inventory. The sample should be selected proportionately across the four ﬁnancial classiﬁcations (tax receiv- ables, compliance assessments, write-offs and memos) and include the following:

representative sample from Individual Master File (IMF) and Business Master File (BMF), representative sample of systemic assessments and manual assess- ments, and tax modules where the sum of the assessed penalty and interest, and/or accrued penalty and interest is greater than $

Note: The Office of Servicewide Interest (OSI) completes a parallel quality of the same sample to verify accuracy of interest computations. The tax modules in the sample also include assessed and/or accrued interest than $
) The project lead maintains a listing of tax modules included in the listing is referred to as the Civil Penalty Review Master Listing. (

) Prior to assignment to the reviewers, the SMEs complete IDRS research analyze the sample to identify the types of civil penalties included in the cycle. Generally, the penalties include: a. failure to ﬁle (FTF) penalty under IRC
), b. failure to pay (FTP) penalty under IRC
), c. estimated tax (ES) penalty under IRC
, d. failure to deposit (FTD) penalty under IRC
, e. bad check penalty under IRC
, and f. the accuracy-related penalty under IRC
) The list above is not all-inclusive (Over
civil penalties are IRS). The sample may include tax modules with other civil penalties that be veriﬁed for accuracy during the review process. (
) In instances where multiple penalties are assessed against the same all civil penalties identiﬁed on the tax module must be veriﬁed for (
) Penalty abatements should be reviewed to the extent possible, based on mation available on the Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) and on Accounts Management Services (AMS).
project lead maintains a listing of tax modules included in the sample. is referred to as the Civil Penalty Review Master Listing.
(10-06-2020) Scope of Civil Penalty Reviews
In instances where multiple penalties are assessed against the same taxpayer, all civil penalties identiﬁed on the tax module must be veriﬁed for accuracy.
20.3 Penalty Program Internal Processes
) Reviewers should document their audit trail so subsequent reviewers can follow steps taken, information and documents reviewed and conclusions reached. (

) Each module reviewed is controlled using a unique control number designated on assignment to the reviewers. Control numbers are generated using the following naming convention: YYYYLNNN • YYYY = the ﬁscal year when the review was conducted (i.e.
) • L = a letter to correspond with the review cycle for the year (i.e. A - ﬁrst cycle, B - second cycle, etc.) • NNN = the control number assigned to the taxpayer module (i.e.
..etc.)
Reviewers should document their audit trail so subsequent reviewers can follow steps taken, information and documents reviewed and conclusions
YYYY = the ﬁscal year when the review was conducted (i.e.
) L = a letter to correspond with the review cycle for the year (i.e. A - ﬁrst cycle, B - second cycle, etc.) NNN = the control number assigned to the taxpayer module (i.e.
..etc.)
Example: 2020A050 is module 50 from the ﬁrst review conducted in ﬁscal year 2020

) Each electronic ﬁle folder should contain the following for all penalty assess- ments and/or abatements reviewed: a. Data Collection Instrument (DCI), b. Copies of IDRS research including: TXMODA, IMFOL/BMFOL, PIFTF failure to ﬁle (FTF) penalties), INTSTD (for failure to pay (FTP) FTDPN (for failure to deposit (FTD) penalties), and COMPAS and (for estimated tax (ES) penalties), c. Copies of lead and computation sheets used for recalculation of the penalty, d. Additional workpapers and spreadsheets used for manual computations and to document ﬁndings, and e. Supporting penalty abatement documentation reviewed, if applicable. (
) Documentation will be uploaded to an enterprise shared folder and retained ﬁve years from the date of issuance of the ﬁnal report of ﬁndings, based on IRM
and Document
, Records Control Schedules. (

) In general, the reviewers analyze IDRS research and utilize veriﬁcation tools (i.e. lead and computation sheets) to review the penalty assessments. (See Civil Penalty Review Job Aid for a detailed explanation of steps taken to conduct the reviews.) Using IDRS research and the veriﬁcation tools, the reviewers recompute each penalty and compare the results to the assessed amount. The reviewers document the computation of each penalty and maintain electronic copies of all IDRS research used to complete the (
) For penalties found to match the assessed amount, the reviewers communi- cate ﬁndings to the project lead and the civil penalty review master listing is updated to reﬂect match. (

) In instances where the penalties do not match the assessment shown on Master File, the reviewers communicate ﬁndings to the project lead and the civil penalty review master listing is updated to reﬂect mismatch. The reviewers consult with the speciﬁc penalty SME to determine if the penalty is true mismatch. The SME conducts additional research and analysis to verify the mismatch (i.e. amount and type), determines the cause of the mismatch and identiﬁes corrective actions needed.

Data Collection Instrument (DCI), Copies of IDRS research including: TXMODA, IMFOL/BMFOL, PIFTF failure to ﬁle (FTF) penalties), INTSTD (for failure to pay (FTP) FTDPN (for failure to deposit (FTD) penalties), and COMPAS and (for estimated tax (ES) penalties), Copies of lead and computation sheets used for recalculation of the penalty, Additional workpapers and spreadsheets used for manual computations and to document ﬁndings, and Supporting penalty abatement documentation reviewed, if applicable.
will be uploaded to an enterprise shared folder and retained years from the date of issuance of the ﬁnal report of ﬁndings, based on 1.15.2 and Document 12990, Records Control Schedules.
Review Process

) The types of mismatches (or errors) found may include: a. manual data entry errors speciﬁc to one taxpayer, b. systemic computational errors affecting many taxpayers, c. processing or procedural errors, and d. use of incorrect information in systemic reference/explanation tools available on IDRS. Note: This list is not all-inclusive. Other types of mismatches may be identiﬁed through this review process. (
) The Civil Penalty Review Master Listing is updated by the project lead to document the ﬁndings. (

) Depending on the type of mismatch, the SMEs identify the actions needed resolve both the systemic root cause and computational errors on the case. Where required, the SMEs input Knowledge Incident/Problem Asset Management (KISAM) tickets to report the issue to Information ogy (IT) for further analysis. Based on their ﬁndings, IT may initiate programming changes affecting systemic computations as necessary. (

) The SMEs contact affected functions (e.g. Automated Substitute for Return (ASFR), Automated Underreporter (AUR), etc.) to request adjustments to correct the errors, as needed. The SMEs keep the program manager and project lead apprised of the status of the mismatches and corrective After corrective actions are requested, the SMEs and/or project lead to take actions to verify corrections were implemented. (

) The SMEs conduct testing to ensure corrective actions are functioning properly. The SMEs document the results of the testing and provide the of testing to the project lead for inclusion as an addendum to the ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings (see IRM
). As needed, affected tax modules may included in subsequent review cycles and rechecked to determine if correc- tions and adjustments were made properly. (
) The SMEs maintain control of the mismatches from identiﬁcation through lution. (
) This section covers the report preparation and dissemination. (

) When the reviews are complete, the reviewers must provide the project with a completed copy of their civil penalty review master listing and all ated ﬁles (included in their electronic ﬁle folders) for review. The project compiles the results into a spreadsheet that encompasses all reviewed tax modules. A report of ﬁndings will be prepared that conveys actions taken, errors identiﬁed (if any) and corrective actions completed (if any).

When the reviews are complete, the reviewers must provide the project lead with a completed copy of their civil penalty review master listing and all associ

ated ﬁles (included in their electronic ﬁle folders) for review. The project lead compiles the results into a spreadsheet that encompasses all reviewed tax modules. A report of ﬁndings will be prepared that conveys actions taken, errors identiﬁed (if any) and corrective actions completed (if any).
20.3 Penalty Program Internal Processes

) The report of ﬁndings is reviewed by the review team members before being presented to the program manager for a ﬁnal review of the document. The Penalty Accuracy program manager reviews and assesses the documented review process, Report results and corrective actions to ensure the report of ﬁndings is accurate and complete. The report of ﬁndings is considered ﬁnal when signed by the program manager. (

) The ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings is shared with Director, Business Support and other leadership, as needed. In addition, the report of ﬁndings will be shared with the CFO, speciﬁcally ROS and IC. The ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings will be uploaded to an enterprise shared folder and retained for ﬁve years the date of issuance of the ﬁnal report of ﬁndings, based on IRM
, and Document
, Records Control Schedules. (

) On ﬁnalization of the report of ﬁndings, if unresolved corrective actions exist, the program manager ensures corrective actions are properly implemented, of Corrective tested and documented as an addendum to the ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings. Identiﬁed in the Penalty Accuracy

On ﬁnalization of the report of ﬁndings, if unresolved corrective actions the program manager ensures corrective actions are properly implemented, tested and documented as an addendum to the ﬁnalized report of ﬁndings.
